results.title: How Trump Could Wreck Things for Republicans in 2024
results.abstract: The governor’s race in New Hampshire offers a window into the ways Trump could complicate the lives of down-ballot G.O.P. candidates.

results.title: The Weekender
results.abstract: The rolled-up painting that might be worth millions. Also in this edition: Sinead O’Connor's legacy, and the ongoing mystery of Covid's origin.

results.byline: By Andrés R. Martínez and Anton Troianovski
results.title: Russia Says 2 Drones Hit Buildings in Moscow in Latest Wave of Attacks
results.abstract: The strike was the third in the past week in Moscow, a sign of how no city in Russia or Ukraine appears to be safe from the war. Russia blamed Ukraine, which has yet to comment.

media.caption: An office building in Moscow after a drone attack on Sunday.

results.adx_keywords: Deaths (Obituaries);Writing and Writers;Books and Literature;Women and Girls;Gender;Psychology and Psychologists;internal-open-access-from-nl;Ruti, Mari (1964-2023)
results.title: Mari Ruti, Scholar of Gender, Sexuality and More, Dies at 59
results.abstract: Her books explored psychoanalytic theories and a range of other topics, including the enduring popularity of a Julia Roberts movie.

media.caption: Mari Ruti in 2010. As both a teacher and a writer, she was known for tackling subjects like how to lead a meaningful life and the effects of rigid gender roles.

results.title: ‘I Opened the Envelope and Found Three Pictures of Me in an Incubator’
results.abstract: An unlikely source of baby photos, a sharp jab to the ribs and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.

results.byline: By Christina Goldbaum and Zia ur-Rehman
results.title: At Least 43 Killed in Blast at Political Rally in Pakistan
results.abstract: An explosion at a political rally on Sunday in northwest Pakistan killed dozens of people and injured 200 more, officials said, the latest sign of the deteriorating security situation in Pakistan, where some militant groups have become more active over the past two years.

media.caption: Outside a hospital on Sunday after an explosion in Bajaur, a district in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa Province near Pakistan’s border with Afghanistan.

results.adx_keywords: Supermarkets and Grocery Stores;Recalls and Bans of Products;Food Contamination and Poisoning;Soups;Falafel;Cookies;Trader Joe's;United States
results.title: Trader Joe’s Recalls Cookies and Falafel Because They ‘May Contain Rocks’
results.abstract: The California-based grocery chain issued a total of three recalls in one week over potential contaminants, including one for a broccoli cheddar soup that “may contain insects.”

media.caption: Trader Joe’s urged customers to either discard the recalled items or return them for a refund.
media.copyright: Gabby Jones for The New York Times

results.title: The English Countryside Is a Place of Profound Inequality
results.abstract: My childhood was spent in the corners of landscaped gardens at a grand country estate. But they weren’t my gardens.

media.caption: The view from the author’s bedroom window at Graythwaite.

results.adx_keywords: Homeless Persons;Drug Abuse and Traffic;Fentanyl;Deaths (Fatalities);George Floyd Protests (2020);Wheeler, Edward Tevis (Ted);Portland (Ore);Multnomah County (Ore);Pearl District (Portland, Ore)
results.title: Fighting for Anthony: The Struggle to Save Portland, Oregon
results.abstract: The city has long grappled with street homelessness and a shortage of housing. Now fentanyl has turned a perennial problem into a deadly crisis and a challenge to the city’s progressive identity.

media.caption: The city has been stepping up efforts to take down tents and relocate people to shelters. But many of them simply packed up their belongings and pitched tents elsewhere.
media.copyright: Amanda Lucier for The New York Times

results.title: Amid the Counterattack’s Deadly Slog, a Glimmer of Success for Ukraine
results.abstract: Recapturing the village of Staromaiorske was such welcome news for the country that President Volodymyr Zelensky announced it himself. But formidable Russian defenses have stymied progress elsewhere.

results.adx_keywords: Libel and Slander;Decisions and Verdicts;Suits and Litigation (Civil);News and News Media;Trump, Donald J;CNN
results.title: Judge Dismisses Trump’s $475 Million Defamation Suit Against CNN
results.abstract: The network’s statements were opinion, the ruling said, and did not support a claim of libel and slander.

media.caption: Donald J. Trump’s lawsuit said CNN’s statements in reference to his efforts to overturn the 2020 election results were tantamount to comparing him to Adolf Hitler and Nazism.
media.copyright: Maddie McGarvey for The New York Times

results.title: The Legacy Dilemma: What to Do About Privileges for the Privileged?
results.abstract: Alumni of many colleges are wrestling with whether the practice of legacy admissions should survive after the Supreme Court gutted race-based admissions programs.

results.title: New York City Had a Migrant Crisis. It Hired a Covid Expert to Help.
results.abstract: DocGo, a medical services firm, has moved hundreds of asylum seekers outside the city as part of its no-bid $432 million contract. Many say they have been threatened and lied to.

media.caption: Although much of DocGo’s expertise is in providing mobile medical services, it was hired by New York City to help with its influx of migrants.

results.byline: By Kate Kelly and David Perlmutt
results.title: Inside the Party Switch that Blew Up North Carolina Politics
results.abstract: Tricia Cotham, a Democrat who supported abortion rights, was encouraged to run for a state House seat by powerful Republicans. After she was elected, she joined them and delivered a G.O.P. supermajority.

media.caption: Tricia Cotham, a state representative in North Carolina, announced that she was switching parties to become a Republican at a news conference in April.

results.title: What ‘Oppenheimer’ Doesn’t Tell You About the Trinity Test
results.abstract: As a new generation of Americans learns about the world’s first nuclear test, the people who lived through it are being left out of the story again.

media.caption: A sign once carried by a victim of radiation from the 1945 atomic bomb test in New Mexico on display at the New Mexico History Museum in Santa Fe in 2019.
